question: What provides the organic matter needed for most fertile soils?

content.source_1: Dead plant material—fallen leaves, stems, and roots—decomposes into humus, adding nutrients to the soil as it breaks down.
content.source_2: Humus formed from decayed vegetation is a major component of soil organic matter and directly supports soil fertility.
content.source_3: Soils with abundant humus/organic matter are typically the most fertile, with better nutrient supply and water-holding capacity.
content.source_4: Biomarker and isotope evidence shows that microbial necromass (e.g., amino-sugar–rich cell-wall residues) constitutes most of the stable soil organic carbon in many productive, fine-textured soils.
content.source_5: The stable fraction of soil organic matter is the part that most strongly governs long-term fertility through improved aggregation, moisture retention, and cation exchange capacity.
content.source_6: In fertile, well-aerated soils, recognizable plant litter turns over quickly; the organic matter that persists and accumulates is predominantly microbially derived.
